body: @jcamachor @julianhyde @b-slim please review.
@nishantmonu51 i guess you have some style issue.
@nishantmonu51 overall looks good to me, left minor comments.
@jcamachor this PR is good to review as well but probably will need to adjust test results once we pull in the other fixes

1. sql should ignore the duplicate sort key
2. SqlToRelConverter should ignore dup key
3. RelCollation should throw (precondition broken) if someone creates a duplicate key or a incompatible key.
@nishantmonu51 thanks fixed

@jcamachor tested handling of timestamp and timestamp_with_tz,
found that when there is a CAST to timestamp and it is possible to get a literal of type timestamp which needs offsetting with correct timezone before sending to druid. Have reused the existing conversion logic from DruidDatetimeUtils to achieve this and added tests. 

Also found another issue with timezone not handled properly in time format extraction fn - 
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2107 will send a follow up PR for that and the case of not accidentally pushing null literal to druid. 

Please check again.
@jcamachor please review.
@julianhyde @jcamachor please review.
@julianhyde please review.
Per discussion at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2112 we're not going to merge this PR at this time.
This was fixed by: https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/489
@tzolov Now that 1.15.0 which was the last release to support JDK 7, we should no longer need to worry about compatibility.
Travis fails because https://github.com/julianhyde/chinook-data-hsqldb is not in Maven Central.

Looks great and very well tested and documented! Just a few minor comments mostly regarding some unnecessary comments which seem to be left in the code. Also, if you could remove the "Created by" comments inserted by IntelliJ, that would be preferred. Thanks for the contribution!
I've merged vlsi/calcite-test-dataset#23 which looks like it's working correctly. However, I'm seeing several of the integration tests for Geode failing.
@julianhyde Please review.

Thanks for the review @michaelmior! Also thanks for merging Geode test dataset!
I will do my best to address the open issues by the end of the week.

@michaelmior i've tried to address your review comments. 
Also I've successfully run the IT tests against the calcite-test-dataset locally.  Which tests are failing  for you?
@tzolov I'll run again now with the latest and post the logs here. Also, before merging it would be great if you could rebase this PR into a single commit.
I ran again and tests pass for me now. If you can rebase this into a single commit, I think this is good to merge! Thanks for the fixes :)
@julianhyde could you please help take a look?

Sorry, I didn't intend to close this PR. In 707f4de I intended to close #571.

If you make further commits, please feel free to re-open this PR.
@tzolov Can you please close this PR, now it has been merged? If I had referenced it in the commit message the ASF hook would have closed it automatically, but I forgot.
Merged in 707f4de9

done!  Thanks @julianhyde!

@eolivelli It use ArrayDeque instead of Stack. Please review again. Thanks
@eolivelli  Thanks again. I think Julian Hyde will review it
Travis triggers tests on calcite plus little different then on my machine - this is a cause of a fail check. Will investigate.
JDK8 build passed ok.
In your commit comment and JIRA subject, describe the benefit to the end-user, not the code change that you made.
The PR looks good overall. @julianhyde, just wondering if we need to consider the streaming window functions, like HOP and TUMBLE.
This is more of a POC to show this is possible. Might need a combination of Docker and non Docker to meet goals.

Failures:
* `jdk-10` - Pig module `NullPointerException`
* `jdk-9-slim` - Missing git for OS test
* `ibmjava` - Error message is different for IBM JDK causing test to fail checking the message
See my comments on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2063.

@julianhyde thanks for the review, and sorry for the delay in addressing the comments (I was ill, and have only recently recovered). In the mean time, it seems that DruidQuery has undergone substantial change, so the changes to that class no longer apply. I have addressed your other comments, removing the defensive coding and introducing asserts as suggested. I have also added a test class for LookupImpl.
@rdsr If you wouldn't mind closing this, it would be helpful in keeping track of issues/PRs that have yet to be addressed. Thanks!

Makes sense Michael. I'll close it.

@suez1224 I have addressed you comments and @julianhyde one.

I still do not have an "useful" logo at the moment which can be adapted to your page.

Alternatively, you can add another predicate that does both is_simple and contains distinct call (`containsDistinctCall()`) check in the rule constructor, as Julian suggested in the issue.

But this will also work. so +1.

@hsyuan , the advice is good.  Maybe it's better to add predicate does following things together in the rule constructor:
1. is_simple
2. not contain DistinctCall()
3. not contain aggregate Call which set filterArgs
4. not contain unSplittable agggregate call.
Now only 1 is in constructor, 3 and 4 still at the beginning of OnMatch method.
Yes, totally agree. Both options are fine to me.

Iâ€™ll take another look.

Removed ibmjava - Will create a separate JIRA for this. Trying jdk-9 to see if git works.

I'm assuming that jdk-10 will still fail until CALCITE-2238 and CALCITE-2239 are fixed. PR #662 is related to that.

Well jdk-9 did not work. So need to see if there is a way to get this to work...

```
[ERROR] Plugin org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-remote-resources-plugin:1.5 or one of its dependencies could not be resolved: Failed to read artifact descriptor for org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-remote-resources-plugin:jar:1.5: Could not transfer artifact org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-remote-resources-plugin:pom:1.5 from/to central (https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2): java.lang.RuntimeException: Unexpected error: java.security.InvalidAlgorithmParameterException: the trustAnchors parameter must be non-empty -> [Help 1]
[ERROR] 
```
It looks like we can get around the JDK 9 ssl issues with `-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=changeit`.

I got approval.

Thank you, please merge

LGTM, let me try it locally
This change brakes the build/tests
Looks like there are some failing unit tests, but they aren't related to the spark/pig changes here. Pushing the change.
Also, please rebase your branch.

We don't usually put a SQL database on the powered-by page when we add its dialect to the JDBC adapter. Maybe it seems "too easy".

Maybe should add a list of supported dialects to https://calcite.apache.org/docs/adapter.html ?

Can you explain the motivation for this test?

"Join" is a misleading name for a function in the SQL world.

Need newline at the end of the .iq file.

Remove "[CALCITE-2088]" from the commit comment. That issue was closed in a previous release. We don't need a JIRA case for a minor commit.

@julianhyde thanks a lot, maybe we can add a section called "supported dialects". What do you think? 

Also, a side question: For SQL dialect, it can be only used to convert a rel into SQL of different dialects, but not the other way around, right? Because the parser can support only one dialect, i.e., the calcite default one.
These failures look to be related to CALCITE-2253. Once CALCITE-2253 is fixed I can rebase and hopefully tests will pass.
The only real change is `- env: IMAGE=maven:3-ibmjava-8` once CALCITE-2063 is fixed can rebase.

A section, or maybe a paragraph. I don't want it to sound too official, because we don't have the resources to properly test each dialect every release.

Does this change come with a VM or other means of testing against Clickhouse? It isn't absolutely necessary but it is preferred.

You are correct, Calcite's parser only supports its own dialect. We have added quite a few optional extensions, so that dialect is fairly forgiving. When we say "support a dialect" we are talking about what the JDBC adapter can generate. It needs to know the capabilities of the target database (e.g. whether it supports window functions) and syntax features (e.g. the character for quoting identifiers).
Rebased since CALCITE-2253 was fixed. Hopefully will get passing results :)

Sweeeeeet. So much green.

I believe Julian is speaking at a conference today/early-week, so I imagine he's slow to respond. I'm OK, but would wait for his OK since he's been involved.
I haven't tried or reviewed, but if Josh is fine with it I am too.
@jcamachor can you please take a look on this?
@vvysotskyi  @julianhyde this is ready for review

HEAD~1 have had a bug in which some user defined functions in json was pushed down to jdbc schema. HEAD at the time of pull creation worked for this pretty ok. So I thought that shipping such test (with custom function in projection of select from jdbc table) would assure that this bug never happen again. Now HEAD is again buggy and this test fails. this @julianhyde this pull can be rejected - I will log JIRA issue for this and attach the branch as a reproduction, ok?
@ptrbojko That makes sense. A PR with a test that fails before and succeeds after is always good.
See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2264
@julianhyde  I've patched here [CALCITE-2264](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2264).
looks good.

Thanks Francis! I don't think we want to automate the push to the site anyway. We commonly selectively update different parts to the site which needs to be done manually. It doesn't really save much doing it automatically anyway.

Tested this out and it seems to work well for me. I'm not sure I would include the Javadoc service for Docker. Anyone developing for Calcite should already have their Java environment set up. Also running things via Docker doesn't really add much benefit and has the potential to cause issues since the Docker container may be running a different JDK than the host environment.

Otherwise, looks great to me!

Thanks for the review Michael! I added the javadoc generation just for completeness for people like me without a proper Java environment setup. However, it's still possible to use the docker container to build the jekyll site and use the local Java environment to generate the Javadocs. The docker containers still write to the `site/target` folder on the host's disk.
Sure, I'm not necessarily -1 on including it. Although if you're not developing Calcite in Java, I'm not sure why you would need to generate the Javadoc.
Makes sense. :+1: Let's see if a few others can review so we can see if there's some consensus on whether it would be useful or not.
closing this as this doesn't seem the correct fix. the problems could be statics or meta generation issues.
Please log a JIRA case for this. Let's discuss. This probably needs to be configurable.
@julianhyde OK! Will do.
@julianhyde Done. I haven't tried to create a JIRA case before, and so please let me know whether it looks good to you: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2301
It seems I've opened this PR with the wrong subject; this is 2247 ; not 2257
Rebasing on current master before pushing. Waiting for tests to finish.
@julianhyde Can you please help review? Thanks

A couple things. I didn't see a JIRA case created for this yet. If you could do that, that would be great. Also, PRs should be a single commit prefixed with `[CALCITE-XXX]` where `XXX` is the JIRA issue number. Whoever commits this can do that for you if needed. Thanks!
This was addressed
Thanks!
